text: Oh, Jimmy, how we miss your talent to shine upon us in this dark hole we live in, to ease our pain and show us that things are not so black and that there is a different way, a way of cathartic purification through art, a place on the top of the mountain closer to sun or god, name it as you like. My heart aches when I see you here and for a moment I believe you are alive. But that sweet pain is more valuable then all of this harsh talentless and boring reality. Jimmy, Jimmy... you break my heart.

text: I still can't quite believe that we will never see James Gandolfini again. This was his last performance before his premature death but The Drop is all about our very own Tom Hardy and he smashes this out of the park.Â  This is a very watchable , claustrophobic crime drama , set in New York and it had me hooked from very early on and kept me on the edge of my seat right to the end . Director, MichaÃ«l R. Roskam has done a great job in getting the best out of this talented cast.Â  Recommended  8 out of 10

text: SPOILERS        Did anyone get the movie? Did Bob have a split personality? Eric being the violent side of him, and Bob being the silent side who everyone really sees? After he shot Eric, you can see him looking into the broken mirror, and he sees Eric. Also, when the two police officers are looking into Eric's psych ward file it is never told which disorder Eric has, but that police officer did look shocked. Bob also asked Eric to stop calling him Bob at the ending. And it would explain why Eric would say he killed Richie Wheelan, but since Bob locks this personality up deep inside of him, he can finally ''kill'' his violent side when he admits that he has one. It could also explain why the Police officer said to Bob at the end ''They can never see you coming'', because the police officer (having read the psych file) knows Bob has a side that nobody, not even himself, knows about.  But even if all this is true, why wouldn't he get arrested. And it also wouldn't make any sense that people who do know Bob, still can see Eric and know he is not the same person. I'm utterly confused.

A good time for the many, a special time for the few who know a little bit more. Tom Hardy has become one of my favorite actors of late: you forget he's acting, he always breaths the roles he plays, a higly intelligent man. Noomi Rapace complemented Tom Hardy perfectly, as well as the other actors, so an Oscar for casting should be in place here. Over all a job well done!

text: Not a credible plot, but credible plots are not essential for good crime movies.Â  Pulp fiction is the shining example, and The Drop is a fine entry to the genre.Â  I have to admit that worrying if Eric Deeds was going to get to Rocco made me a nervous wreck throughout most of the movie.Â  Same fear has kept me from watching John Wick, which I hear is also very good.Â

text: Did anyone else watch this and feel like they were taking one last glimpse at Tony Soprano? I was so high I was almost convincing myself that Tony somehow was able to survive the New York vs New Jersey war but for some reason had to leave town and lay low. That's when he switched his name to Marv and started a new life and a new hustle. Gandolfini sounds like he used the same accent he did on the show. I was devastated when I heard he passed away. I'm glad I got to take one last glance at the character that made him one of my favorite actors... Let me reiterate my point though, I was really, really high when I watched this. Lol. Great movie though.

text: The Drop.   Bob Saginowski (Tom Hardy) tends bar in his cousin's pub (James Gandolfini) and looks the other way when local mobsters use the joint as a temporary bank. His simple life takes a complicated turn when he finds a battered puppy. He asks his neighbor, Nadia (Noomi Rapace), for help nursing it back to health. 7/10 https://www.facebook.com/Shadrachart/photos/a.860846417302238.1073741833.102380556482165/883676615019218/?type=3
